author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body: - https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/93707#issuecomment-1770541435

Your `new package` pull request met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have read the package naming guidelines: https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

> If your package is at a stage where it might be useful to others, or provide functionality other packages in General might want to rely on, go for it!

This package is at a stage where it might be useful to me when I'm having fun poking around with what Julia can do in terms of language extensions. I've been thinking in the past about something similar to this for a mainstream non-English language, and this would be interesting prior art to consider.

> The General registry is open for everyone to register packages in. The General registry is not a curated list of Julia packages. In particular this means that:
>
> - packages included in the General registry are not reviewed/scrutinized;
> - packages included in the General registry are not "official" packages and not endorsed/approved by the JuliaLang organization;
> - the General registry and its maintainers are not responsible for the package code you install through the General registry -- you are responsible for reviewing your code dependencies.

@moelf, The standard is not "do I think folks should use this in production code?", the standard is "could anyone plausibly benefit from this and is it okay to permanently assign this package that name?"

This seems strictly more reasonable than https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/35322.

Given that this package meets the posted criteria for inclusion in General, and is strictly more reasonable than an already registered package, I support merging.

[noblock]

>could anyone plausibly benefit from this

not any reasonable benefit.

#35322 is in the same bin from my perspective, it slipped through doesn't mean it's a good example

- - -

those guidelines shouldn't be regarded as the full requirement, we can use some common sense here, for example, if someone tries to add a package similar to https://www.npmjs.com/package/is-odd, it doesn't break anything, but clearly we shouldn't

You say "not any reasonable benefit" but 
But @LilithHafner just said above:

> This package is at a stage where it might be *useful* to me when I'm having fun poking around with what Julia can do in terms of language extensions. I've been thinking in the past about something similar to this for a mainstream non-English language, and this would be interesting prior art to consider.

[noblock]

> This package is at a stage where it might be useful to me when I'm having fun poking around with what Julia can do in terms of language extensions.

Apologies to be blunt, but are you joking? The package is 38 lines of `const` aliases and oneliner macros; far removed from any form of "language extension".

Sure, it's funny that one can do that and that you can bring "GenZ lingo" into a programming language that way; but should this really be merged to a registry of packages that provide functionality above just some aliases?

In my view, the package is funny, but doesn't have functionality. So, I think it doesn't clear the bar for being non-empty:

> Some types of packages should not be registered, or are not yet ready for registration:
> [...]
>  * "Empty" packages that do not yet have functionality are not ready to be registered.

There's nothing in this package that you couldn't do without it.

[noblock]
That's kind of the whole point of language extension. Sure you can express every emotion in standard English, every function in standard Julia, but there's still an argument for learning other languages (human or programming).

Do you really intend for other packages to be able to depend on this one @chelseas, and think it provides useful functionality that they would want to use? 

If so it seems ok to me. It seems different than the personal utility packages that that rule was added for, eg the name is pretty specific rather than something like Utilities.jl or whatever.

> There's nothing in this package that you couldn't do without it.

That‚Äôs basically true for any package though, given you could just vendor the code.

[noblock]
Yes @ericphanson I could see people building other packages on top of this.

> Do you really intend for other packages to be able to depend on this one @chelseas, and think it provides useful functionality that they would want to use?

If @chelseas wants to develop the package further to a point where it provides that functionality, sure - but I don't think it's at that stage now. Providing some `const` aliases doesn't clear that bar of functionality.

>That‚Äôs basically true for any package though, given you could just vendor the code.

I personally think it's over generalization to say "all packages are just vendoring some Julia code". There's a clear difference in defining some `const` and `macro` alias vs. actual algorithms getting written

> I could see people building other packages on top of this.

I guess we‚Äôve been beating around the bush. It would be a bad idea for anyone to use this package ‚Äúfor production‚Äù, as it produces completely unintelligible code. Thus, I would consider having it in General to be harmful, and as a community, we should actively prevent the package from being used.

It‚Äôs funny as a joke or ‚Äúart project‚Äù and I‚Äôm all for that, but let‚Äôs leave it at that. Sorry to be blunt. I really do appreciate the joke, but registering it is taking it a step too far.

[noblock]

I'm not sure where the backlash comes from. General is an intentionally uncurated registry of packages, there's no hard requirement on usefulness or correctness or anything other than it being "not malicious".

>"all packages are just vendoring some Julia code"

I didn't say that. I said you can replace any package by a copy of it's code placed directly in your source tree, which is trivially true. The point being 

> There's nothing in this package that you couldn't do without it.

isn't a good standard. I'm not saying there should be no standard, I'm just saying that isn't a good one.

> > There's nothing in this package that you couldn't do without it.
>
> isn't a good standard. I'm not saying there should be no standard, I'm just saying that isn't a good one.

That's a good point, so permit me to clarify what I meant - the package as it is now bears a striking resemblance to those "personal utility package"s that the rule was originally meant to capture. So in a world where this package is registered, can someone with their personal favorite collection of `const` alias definitions also register that package? That'd mean the personal utility rule would be quite useless, as the line between "package providing functionality" and "personal utility package" gets blurrier and blurrier, even more so than the wording in the current README is.

The reason that rule exists, as I understand it, is exactly to prevent this kind of custom aliasing of names, with nothing else on top; there is the minimum standard (even in General) that a package must provide some functionality of its own, and this package (to my eyes) simply doesn't pass that bar.

> there's no hard requirement on usefulness or correctness or anything other than it being "not malicious".

Well, yeah, but if I take 

> I am not joking.

at face value, then I would consider it malicious. I mean, not "malicious" in that just the existence of the package would cause any great harm, but I would certainly raise an eyebrow (and probably a blocking comment) on any registration of a package built on top of it: I don't think we should allow code obfuscation in General.

I actually don't believe @chelseas that they're not joking, though. I think they're trying to see how far they can get with this, which I appreciate as a bit of lighthearted trolling. But still, no.

That being said, I'm not going to hold a grudge if someone with merge rights overrides the objection and merges this. ;-) It's a judgement call.

[noblock]

So I work at a university and I actually think that this would be a fun and engaging teaching tool, genuinely. 
I don't understand why so many people are so triggered by the existence of this package. If you don't like it, don't use it.

> So I work at a university and I actually think that this would be a fun and engaging teaching tool, genuinely.

I agree with that, but it doesn't need to be registered for that.

> I don't understand why so many people are so triggered by the existence of this package. If you don't like it, don't use it.

I don't really object to this package as such, but I would object to packages being registered using this. Since every dependency of a package in General also has to be in General, the best way to guarantee that is to not have `GlowupVibes` in General.

[noblock]

Maybe have a [GlowupRegistry](https://github.com/GunnarFarneback/LocalRegistry.jl) for this package, and then your students can register their projects using `GlowupVibes` there as well. It could be a good for teaching them about registration, and completely removes the danger of them trying to submit their semester project to General.

[noblock]

>So I work at a university and I actually think that this would be a fun and engaging teaching tool, genuinely.

I agree but that's pretty squarely in private usage though, student can easily just `]add url`, or in fact, you probably should prepare `Manifest.toml` for your students to make sure every one has the same environment

[noblock] cus I don't want to refresh the block timer

> So I work at a university and I actually think that this would be a fun and engaging teaching tool, genuinely.

Well, the README for General does have something to say about that too:

> nor for packages that are only useful for a closed group (like a research group or a company)

But okay, let's assume it's for other people to teach as well. What should be taught here? The README of your package certainly doesn't say anything of the sort.
[noblock] Well, based on the various up and down votes, it seems like there's a ~consensus~ majority opinion to let the registration proceed, so make sure to edit your comments to contain `[noblock]`

If this were supporting a personal language/dialect with a closed group of speakers, then the personal use objections would be valid. But this package supports a dialect that is widely used.

[noblock]

I don't see the problem. They are just saying how they would personally use it - why mightn't others feel the same and use it as a fun example? I think it could be fun to demonstrate what you can do (and a nice way to demonstrate the use of unicode in code :-) ).

I'm particularly not convinced that just because others might not want to depend on this directly in their packages it shouldn't be registered. Seems like a bunch of different weak reasons being given, especially given the precedent that there are already several other packages that fit a similar theme. 

[noblock]

>But this package supports a dialect that is widely used.

Programming languages are not natural languages. Should we start having a Chinese keyword `const` package? Chinese is clearly widely used.

This line of argument is just not applicable for a programming language.

- - -
>I'm particularly not convinced that just because others might not want to depend on this directly in their packages it shouldn't be registered.

arguably, in this particular case, depending on this package is actively harmful. There are languages that call a row a column and a column a row. I think it can be agreed that if they define a bunch of `const` that switch `row` and `column` in function names such as `eachrow()` and `eachcolumn()`, and start using that in a corner of the ecosystem, it would be very confusing. This package at least doesn't switch names around, but IMO it can also be actively confusing if people actually depend on this package

[noblock]

@LilithHafner @DanielVandH so you think we should have i18 const-defining packages that "support" different language people write around the world?

[noblock]

Yes, we should absolutely support Chinese and other languages. You should be able to write `using Chinese` at the top of your file and write everything else in Chinese. The fact that this package is much simpler and does not provide full coverage (e.g it does not cover keywords like `using`, `for` and `if`) should not prevent it from being registered.

As for critiques about the source code of this package, a simple implementation is good, not bad.

But we digress.

Let's try to keep this discussion focused on whether or not this package meets the criteria for inclusion in the general registry.

[noblock]

> so you think we should have i18 const-defining packages that "support" different language people write around the world?

Why not? It would be great to make things easier for non-English speakers. It's unfortunate that everything has to be English. But this is not relevant to this topic.

> There are languages that call a row a column and a column a row. I think it can be agreed that if they define a bunch of const that switch row and column in function names such as eachrow() and eachcolumn(), and start using that in a corner of the ecosystem, it would be very confusing. This package at least doesn't switch names around, but IMO it can also be actively confusing if people actually depend on this package

I don't think this example is relevant - nothing is being switched around. 



I think unless the general registry decides it wants to have stricter standards and actually has them written down, this is fine.

[noblock]

>I don't think this example is relevant - nothing is being switched around.

it is relevant because the effects is the same, originally a human programmer can look at the code:
```julia
sum(ary)
```

now you can see:
```julia
Russian: —Å—É–º–º–∞(–º–∞—Å—Å–∏–≤)
Chinese: ÊÄªÂíå(Êï∞ÁªÑ)
Japanese: ÂêàË®à(ÈÖçÂàó)
Hindi: ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó(‡§∏‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä)
```

that's effectively what's happening with this package: you need to chase that indirection to find out what the heck the `const` definition is, and it's basically pointless because it's just a `const` definition.

[noblock]

maybe I should take the blame for blocking this auto merge in the first place. I suspect this degree of bike shedding is not worth anyone's time including OP's. Someone should just merge this and let's move on.

[noblock]
I'm willing to merge once the 3 day period is up, given no registry maintainers have objected ü§∑. But might as well stick to the usual procedure with the 3 day period.

[noblock]

Is there another package that is better deserving of the name GlowupVibes? This pkg be bussin AF.
